forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
You have to check, because most certainly every BIOS should allow at least booting USB-attached floppy (part of legacy USB support), so this is a kind of USB booting. I assume you already checked all BIOS options?  

My 6/7-year old laptop has Phoenix BIOS too, and it can boot at USB 2.0 speed without any problem.

forumNotes.content:
Strangely enough, portable hardware like laptops, which in real world are used a lot with protable devices (read USB devices) tend to, generally speaking, lack the USB booting choices that desktops usually have. forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
> My new notebook has USB 2.0 Hi-Speed but unfortunately the BIOS has no option to boot from USB.  
>
> It's a PhoenixBIOS. On the manufactors site (fujitsu siemens) there is a BIOS update.

My Phoenix BIOS does not have any specific option to boot from USB. I just plug my USB HDD, then boot the system, then go to BIOS.  
In the boot pioriry/HDD list, the USB disks appear with "-USB" suffix, the primary internal HDD appears with "-PM" suffix (for primary master I assume).  
So I just change the boot priority (F5, F6) to set my desired USB HDD on top of the list to boot from this USB HDD.
